provenance.name: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens
provenance.note: Given by Blake to Charles Tulk c. 1810; sold by Edward Duperner, Sotheby's, 20 June 1906, lot 937, £109 to B. F. Stevens; acquired by Robert Hoe, who rebound it in 1908; auctioned from Hoe's estate by Anderson Auction Company, 25 April 1911, lot 389, to George D. Smith for $725 for Henry Huntington; now in the Huntington Library.

repository.institution: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens

illustration.illusobjdec: Pictured in an oval frame in the center of the plate, a resting figure — almost certainly Samson — lies unconscious and limp on the ground. He is muscular and bare-chested, and wears a cloth or loincloth around his waist. His body faces left, and his face faces forward and tilts slightly to the right. His head, with curly hair, rests against his bare left shoulder. His eyes are closed. His left arm bends ninety degrees at elbow so that his clenched fist rests on his lap, while his right forearm extends over his right thigh. One finger of his right hand is pointed, as the hand drapes over his inner thigh. Samson’s upper body is propped upright against the legs of a woman standing behind him. This woman is most likely Delilah. She wears a gown with a bodice or vest over her torso and has dark hair that is pulled into a bun. She bends forward and reaches her left arm downward to support or hold up the unconscious Samson. Her left hand is held behind his back. Her head, turned to look behind her, is encircled with a strip of cloth. She may be blindfolded. A group of three men stand behind her. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk’s Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. The central figure in the group wears the uniform of a Roman solider, including a helmet and tunic. His body faces forward and his legs are spread apart, with the left leg extended to the left and the right leg bent at the knee (although it is mostly obscured by Delilah’s dress). He twists his upper body to the right, and bends his right arm upward at the elbow to cross over his chest. His face is turned downward and to the left to look at the ground or, perhaps, at Samson. A cloak or cape billows from his back to his left, and it may be worn by him or by the figure to his right. To the right of the central figure, a man with long white hair looks downward and to the right. His body faces right, and his left arm extends outward to grab a curtain, visible at the edge of the frame. Only his upper body is visible, but he appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure. To the left of the central figure, a third figure, likely a male with long dark hair, faces the right. His upper body and face are obscured by the central figure, so that only his legs are visible. His legs are spread, with one leg extended backward and the other bent at the knee, as if he is lunging. He appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure. A column is visible behind and to the left of the figures, and they appear to stand or lay on a hard floor. A curtain or drapery extends from the top of the oval frame to the lower third of both sides. The oval frame sits within a backdrop that appears to be of bricks. Above the oval frame, there is a stone or marble plaque. Below the plaque, there is the statue or sculpture of the head of a figure, perhaps a female. Her long curly hair extends to either side, and from both sides of hair two pieces of cloth or drapery extend, draped to the sides and upward, where it hangs over two hooks on either side of the plaque. The ends of the cloth twist over itself to form two loops on either side. A second plaque sits below the oval frame.

component.illusobjdesc: Pictured in an oval frame in the center of the plate, a resting figure — almost certainly Samson — lies unconscious and limp on the ground. He is muscular and bare-chested, and wears a cloth or loincloth around his waist. His body faces left, and his face faces forward and tilts slightly to the right. His head, with curly hair, rests against his bare left shoulder. His eyes are closed. His left arm bends ninety degrees at elbow so that his clenched fist rests on his lap, while his right forearm extends over his right thigh. One finger of his right hand is pointed, as the hand drapes over his inner thigh. Samson’s upper body is propped upright against the legs of a woman standing behind him.

A woman, most likely Delilah, stands behind Samson. She wears a gown with a bodice or vest over her torso and has dark hair that is pulled into a bun. She bends forward and reaches her left arm downward to support or hold up the unconscious Samson. Her left hand is held behind his back. Her head, turned to look behind her and away from the viewer, is encircled with a strip of cloth. She may be blindfolded.

A group of three men stand behind Delilah. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk’s Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. The central figure in the group wears the uniform of a Roman solider, including a helmet and tunic. His body faces forward and his legs are spread apart, with the left leg extended to the left and the right leg bent at the knee (although it is mostly obscured by Delilah’s dress). He twists his upper body to the right, and bends his right arm upward at the elbow to cross over his chest. His face is turned downward and to the left to look at the ground or, perhaps, at Samson. A cloak or cape billows from his back to his left, and it may be worn by him or by the figure to his right.

A group of three men stand behind Delilah. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk’s Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. To the right of the central figure, a man with long white hair looks downward and to the right. His body faces right, and his left arm extends outward to grab a curtain, visible at the edge of the frame. Only his upper body is visible, but he appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure.

A group of three men stand behind Delilah. These figures may be the “fooman” in “The Monk’s Tale,” to whom Delilah sells Samson. To the left of the central figure, a third figure, likely a male with long dark hair, faces the right. His upper body and face are obscured by the central figure, so that only his legs are visible. His legs are spread, with one leg extended backward and the other bent at the knee, as if he is lunging. He appears to wear a tunic similar to that of the central figure.
The background is scarcely detailed, but there is a visible column behind and to the left of the figures. They appear to stand or lay on a hard floor.
A curtain or drapery extends from the top of the oval frame to the lower third of both sides.
The oval frame over backdrop or façade that appears to be made of bricks. The oval frame casts a slight shadow over the bricks.

Above the oval frame, there is the statue or sculpture of the head of a figure, perhaps a female. Her long curly hair extends to either side, and from both sides of hair two pieces of cloth or drapery extend, draped to the sides and upward, where it hangs over two hooks or posts on either side of a plaque. The ends of the cloth twist over itself to form two loops on either side.
Two plaques, which may be made of marble or stone, are positioned above and below the oval frame. Each plaque contains a frame, within which text is engraved.
